p.s: Small but important steps - Germany remains optimistic after COP26
After the COP26 in Glasgow, opinions have been divided.

While some may argue that the aims that have been expressed an agreed on, Will not be sufficient to meet the 1.5°-mark, up until then the effects of global warming are still reversible, others are more optimistic.
Surely, there have been setbacks, most prominently changing the goal from putting a stop to fossil fuel production, to merely ending production step-by-step.
However, in the grand scheme of things the acceptance of this alone is a success in itself – especially if even states such as India and China who still heavily rely on fossil fuel energy agree.
No, contrary to the conferences about the Paris agreement in 2016, there is a common agreement that fossil fuels are meant to be left in the past, and COP26 proves just that.

Some States who have experience the effects of climate change stronger than others have urged everyone at Glasgow to take action against global warming, hopefully COP26 was able to send a sign of hope to them.
Considering we are currently looking at 2.7° instead of 5-6° like we were in 2016, Germany's optimism is reasonable.

Jochen Flasbarth, Germany's negotiator at COP26, reminds us in an interview with ARD-Morgenmagazin, that conferences alone will not be able to solve the climate crisis but the legal basis that was created during the conference, surely will help for future negotiations and actions.
He concludes that Glasgow might not have been a huge step forward, but it was an important and necessary one.
